review.title: Mining Best Closed Itemsets for Projection-antimonotonic Constraints in Polynomial Time
review.abstract: The exponential explosion of the set of patterns is one of the main challenges in pattern mining. This challenge is approached by introducing a constraint for pattern selection. One of the first constraints proposed in pattern mining is support (frequency) of a pattern in a dataset. Frequency is an anti-monotonic function, i.e., given an infrequent pattern, all its superpatterns are not frequent. However, many other constraints for pattern selection are neither monotonic nor anti-monotonic, which makes it difficult to generate patterns satisfying these constraints.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: "Interesting measures have been proposed to overcome the problem of the combinatorial explosion of the number of valid patterns that can be detected in a1ar Xiv: 170 3.09 513v 1dataset [VT14]. For example, the number of patterns captured by the pattern is one of the most famous metrics for the stability of patterns. In particular, the support fulfills the property of anti-monotonicity (aka" a priori principle "), i.e., the larger pattern is the smaller threshold of support [MTV94, AS94]. Many other metrics can be mentioned, such as sample stability [Kuz07, ROK08], margin proximity [MTU11], MCCS [SDB13], cosmic interest [CWWW14], sample robustness [TMC14], etc. Some of these metrics (e.g. support, robustness for MCCS], or upper limitations of MCCS [SDB13] are global."

sections.heading: 3.3 Σοφια Algorithm for Closed Itemsets
sections.text: Here we show how to adjust your algorithm for closed patterns. A closed pattern in closed pattern is not necessarily closed pattern (T, {i1, i2}, R2), but no longer closed pattern (T, {i1, i2, i3}, R3). However, the extents (closed tidsets) in this pattern are extents in D [GK01]. Therefore, we associate the closed patterns with extents and then work with extents instead of patterns, i.e., a dataset D = (T, (2I, i3}, R3) is converted to extents (closed tidsets) of D (D).

sections.heading: 4 Itemset Constraints
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 4.1 Cosine Interest of an Itemset
sections.text: The first projected antimonotonic measure we considered is the cosine interest rate [CWW14], which is defined by cosine (X) = | t (X) | | X | √ i-X | t ({i}) |, (4) i.e. a cosine interest of X is the support of X via the geometric mean of the support of individual items from X. As the authors of [CWW14] have shown, this measurement is not (anti-) monotonous. Then they also showed that when we traverse the search space from less supported items to more supported items, the cosine interest never decreases. In fact, in the face of an item set X and an item set i, we can see that i-X and i-X-t ({i) | t ({j}) | Cosine (X) and Cosine (X) cannot decrease because the itemset support cannot increase while the mean value cannot decrease in this case.

sections.heading: 4.2 Stability and Robustness of an Itemset
sections.text: Stability [Kuz07] and robustness [TMC14] are similar metrics when applied to closed item sets. They measure the independence of an item set w.r.t. subsampling. Stability can only be applied to closed item sets, while robustness is defined for any kind of item set constraints (closed item sets, generators, etc.). However, the coherence of items is not an antimonotonic ability. Since stability and robustness are similar, we define them on similar bases. In the face of a dataset D = (T, I, R), a triple (S, I, R), where S T is called a subdataset.

sections.text: Let us look at the example in Figure 1 and show how we can find all Δ-stable item sets with threshold θ = 2. We have a binary dataset D = (T, {i1, · ·, i6}, R). Let us call Ii = {i1, · ·, ii}. The sets Ii correspond to a chain of projects.In Table 2, all closed item sets are given by the corresponding tidsets, i.e. by elements of DC. For the sake of simplicity, we write 1234 instead of {t1, t2, t3, t4}. For each element Δ measure is shown for each Ii. A cell is shown in grey if the item set is no longer taken into account (the value of Δ is less than 2). For example, in the transition from I2 to I3, the set 1234 is discarded (1234) and the set 1234 (123y 123y) is discarded as 121.

sections.heading: 5 Experiments and Discussion
sections.text: It is not the first time that the EU Commission has taken such a step.

sections.heading: 5.1 Comparing Computational Efficiency
sections.text: We use publicly available big datasets of FIMI2, LUCS [Coe03] and UCI [FA10]. The experiments are run on an "Intel (R) Core (TM) i7-2600 CPU @ 3.40GHz" calculator with 8Gb of memory under Ubuntu 14.04.We should note two points if we know the best of our knowledge that the calculation of top stable and robust itemsets so that there are no direct competitors. In addition, the calculation of data for an itemset requires either a known partial order of itemsets or a search for its offspring (closed supersets). Therefore, as approximate competitors, we have decided to use two algorithms LCMv3 [ZH05].

sections.heading: 5.2 Scalability
sections.text: First, we can measure the time it takes to find top L concepts, i.e. how the memory constraint L changes efficiency, as shown in Table 4 for the same datasets. We can see that the calculation time changes linearly, as expected by Equation. (3) Finally, we check how the calculation time depends on the size of the dataset. To do this, we conduct our experiments for L = 1000 and vary the number of transactions in a dataset. We permutate the transaction sequence of the dataset several times. For each permutation, we construct datasets that contain a certain amount (the size of the dataset) of the first transactions from that permutation. Calculation time is averaged over the permutations. Figure 2 shows the calculation time it takes to process a certain fraction of the transactions in the dataset.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we have introduced a new class of metrics for interest, the so-called projection antimonotonous metrics. This broad class of metrics includes classical anti-monotonous, locally anti-monotonous and some non-monotonous metrics. We have introduced an algorithm that enables patterns to be efficiently broken down. We have studied stability and robustness, introduced two projection antimonotonous metrics and polynomial estimates of these metrics, the so-called Δ-measure. Finally, in the experimental part, we have shown that we can find stable metrics much more efficiently than subsequent approaches. Many approaches for future work are promising. First, we should work on adapting communication projects to deal with different types of pattern structures, e.g. based on sequences or diagrams. Second, the introduction of new data mining approaches through projections of a specific kind, so that it is possible to study other types of measurements for stability and stability [05].

metadata.abstractText: The exponential explosion of the set of patterns is one of the main challenges in pattern mining. This chalenge is approached by introducing a constraint for pattern selection. One of the first constraints proposed in pattern mining is support (frequency) of a pattern in a dataset. Frequency is an anti-monotonic function, i.e., given an infrequent pattern, all its superpatterns are not frequent. However, many other constraints for pattern selection are neither monotonic nor anti-monotonic, which makes it difficult to generate patterns satisfying these constraints. In order to deal with nonmonotonic constraints we introduce the notion of “projection antimonotonicity” and Σοφια algorithm that allow generating best patterns for a class of nonmonotonic constraints. Cosine interest, robustness, stability of closed itemsets, and the associated Δ-measure are among these constraints. Σοφια starts from light descriptions of transactions in dataset (a small set of items in the case of itemset description) and then iteratively adds more information to these descriptions (more items with indication of tidsets they describe). In the experiments, we compute best itemsets w.r.t. some measures and show the advantage of our approach over postpruning approaches.
